Rohesplerre, to ayenge his injured vanity, OF
to remove rival whom he envled; Marat,
from the same instructive love Oh oiooo,
which induces a wolf to continue his ravaBc
of the focks long after his hunger is appeas-
ed.''


"Danton despised Robespierre for his
cowardice, Robespierre feared the ferocious
audacity of Danton, and with him, to tear
was to hate--and to hate was-when the
hour arrived--to destroy They differed IN
their ideas also of the mode OF exercising
their terrible system Of government. Danton
had often in his mouth the sentence OF Ma
chiaval, that when it becomes necessary to
shed blood, a single great massacre has


more dreadfnl effect than series OF success
i've exer.ions. Robespierre. on the contra.
ry, preferred the latter, rs the best way OF
sustaining the reign Of terror The appe-
tite of Marat could not be satiated but by
combining both modes Of murder both
Danton and Robespierre kept aloof from the
sanguinary Marat.


Among the three monsters mentioned,
Danton had that energy which the Giron-
dists wanted and was we'll acquainted with
the secret movrnents OF those insurrections
TO which they possessed no key. His vices
of wrath, luxury, love Cf spoil, dreadful as
they were, arc attributes OF mortal men;-
the envy OF Rohespierre, and the instructive
blood-thirstiness Of Marat were the proper
ties of hends. Danton, like the huge SER
pent called the Boa, might be approached
with degree Of safety when gorged with
prey; but the appetite of Marat tor blood
was like the horse lccch, which says, Not
cnough--an,: the slaughterous envy of Rob-
espierre was like the knawing worm that
dieth not, and yields no Interval OF repose.-
In glutting Danton with spoil, and furnish
ing the means of indulgins his luxury, the
Girondists might have purchased his sup
port; but nothing under the supreme rule of
France would have gratiicd Eobcspierre,-
and AN unlimited torrent of the blood of that
unhappy country, could alone have satiated
I Marat. II 4 colleague was to be chosen cut
OF that dctrstab,c triumvirate, uuquestiona-
bly, Dantpn was 10 be considered the most
eligible

The boarding officer was an acquaintance OF
a Spanish gentleman, passenger in the La

l.aborde had sent formal challenge "

The local circumference has been found
TO he .lSS feet, which gives to the ruins 4
much greater extrnt uf base than the origi-
nal building Thc surplus is very great,
"nen one considers the qaantity that must
have been removed by the Macedonian SOL
diers, aud hos much, in the course OF ages,
must have been taken by the workmcn en-
ployed in digging for bricks. lhc elevation
ut the mound is irregular 10 tile west it is
,9S feet high Ga the top is that which
looked like castle in the distance; it is a
solid mass ci kiln blrnt bricks, thirty seven
feet high, and twenty-eight broad. The
bricks, which are ct ali excellent desciip-
ton, are laid in with fine and scarce.
y perceptiblc cement. At regular inter-
yals, some bricks are omitted so as to leave
square apertures through the mass these
may possibly have been intended to procure
free current Of air, that should prevent the
admission OF damp into the brick work. The
summit Of the mass is much broken, and the
fractures are 80 made as to carry conviction
that violence has been used to reduce it to
this state.


Distant from the pile oi bricks Just describ
ed, and lower down on the north face of the
large mound, IS another mass exactly SINH
lar. Pieces Of marble, stones, and broken
bricks. iie scattered over the ruin. The
most curious Of the fragments are several
mis-shapen masses OF brick work quite
black, except in few places where regular
layers Of kiln-burnt bricks are disccrnabe:
these have certainly been subjected to some
fierce heat, as they are completely molten
ia strong presumption that fire was used
in the destruction OF the tower; which, in
parts, resembles that what the scriptures
prophcsicd il should become, IA burnt munh
tain"


Travellers who have visited this spot have
been struck with the curious appearance Of
these fragments, and having only seen the
black fee, have altogether rejected
the idea of their being bricks. In the de-
nnncations respecting Babylon. fire is par
tcnlarly mentioned as an agent against it,
10 this Jeremiah evidently alludes, when
he says that it should be as "whrn God o.
yerthrew Sodom and Comorrah," on which
cities, it is said ''the Lord rained fire and
birthstone" Again. 81 will kindle fire in
his cities, and it shall devour all round about
him" and in another place, cher high gates
shall be burned with fire, and the people
shall labonr in vain, and the folk in the fire,
and they shall be weary"


Taking into calculation the brick mass On
the top of the large mound, tne runs are
two hundred and thirty five fett.hgh, which
gives nearly half the height of the tower in
its perfect state. Rich thought he could
trace four stages or stories of this building;
and the united observations of our party in
duce the same conviction.


Wild beasts appeared to be as numerous
here as at Mujillele. Mr.. Lamb gave up
his examination, from seeing an animal
crouched in one of the square aperturcs.
saw another in n similar situation, and the
large Footprint of lion was so fresh, that
the beast must have stolen away on our ap-
preach. From the summit we had view
of the vast heaps which constitute all that
now remains of ancient Babylon; more
complete picture of desolation could not be


imagined. The eye wandered over bar
rem desert, in which ruins were the only in
dication that it had ever been ,nhabited.-
It was impossible TO behold this scene, and
not to be reminded how exactly the predic-
tion of Isaiah ard Jeremiah have been full
filled, even in the appearance Babylon was
doomed to present: that "she should never
be nhabited;" that "the Arabian should not
pitch his tent there" that she would ',be-
become heaps" that her cities should be
"a desolation, dry land, and Wilderness"

AN ACT to extend the time Of issuing and locat-
ing Military Land Warrants to Officers and Sol
diers of the Revolutionary Army.


Be il enacted by the Senate and House of
Representatives Of the United States Of II
merica in Congress Assembicd, That the
time limited by the second section of the Act
approved, the twenty fourth day of February,
one thousand eight hundred and nineteen, for is
suing military Land Warrants to the Officers and
Soldiers Of the Revolutionary Army, shall be ex-
tended till the fourth day Of March, one thous.
and eight hundred and thirty; and the time fo,
locating the indicated warrants shall be extend
ed till the first day ofOctober thereafter.
APPROVED: March 2, 1897.

DANTON, ROBESPlEKRE, AND Mhhhi'


We come, next, to the Legislative As
sembiy, Gin which there was no party, that
could be termed strictly or properly royal
ists." It's three divisions, the Constitution
alists, the Girondists, or Brissotins and the
Jacobins, are exhibited in their diversity OF
traits and objects; their relentless mutual
strife, and their common warfare against
the wretched king. The Girondists and the
Jacebins stood ready "to storm together tne
last bulwarks of the monarchy"-but the
latter were resolved and destined to monop-
olize the spoil, and establish the incttable'
incompatible Reign Of Terror. Robes
pierre, SAYS Scott. might be CONSIDERED as
the head of the Jacobins, if they had, IN
deed leader. more than two wolves nave
which tune their united voices to cry OF MN
that bays .hc loudest" Mdrdt loved TO
talk of murder as soldiers do OF battles, and
made, con dm0re, an exact calcuia'loh 10
shaw in what manner tzoo hundred ana S'1-
, ty thousand aristocrats might be Dutchered
in a day. The two peerless rufflans, ana
their condign associate, Ddnton, are thus
portrayed in the second volume -


"Ihree men of terror, whose names VIII
long remain, we trust, unmatched III histo-
~ BY those Of any similar mlscreants, had
1
and were called the triumviratc.


I Danton deserves to, be named first, as un-
rivaled by his colleagues in talent and au-
dacity. He was man of gigantic size, and
possessed voice Of thunder, His counte-
nance WAS that of an Orge on the shoulders
OF a Hercules. He was as fond of the pleas
urcs of vice as Of the practice of cruclty'
and it was id THAT there were times when he
became humani2ed amidst his dcbauchery,
| laughed at the terror which his furious dec
/ lamations excited, and might be approached
with safety. ike the Maelstrom at the turn
of tide. II p,ofision was inlulgcd to an
extent hazardous to his potMlaritv, for the
populace are jcalous ola lavish expenditure,
AS raising their favoritcs too much above
their owu d gree: and the charge OF spccu
lltiun finds always ready credit with them,
when brought agains. public men.


Rohcspcrre possessed this advantage over
Danton, that he did not seem to seek fG'
wealth. either for hording or expenains, bG'
lived in strict and economical retirement, tc
Justify the name of thr Incorrtptiblc, wi;h
which he was honored BY his partizaps. He
appears to have possessed little talents, saw
ing q dcep fund Vt hypncrisv, considerable
powers Of sophistry, and Il cold exaggerated
strain Of oratorv, as foreign 70 good taste, a'
the measures he recommended were 70 or
binary humanity. II Itseemed wonderful that
even the serthiue and boiling Of the revoil'
tionarv cauldron. should have sent up trou
the bottom, and long supported OH the sur
! face, a thing so miserabv void Of claims Il
public distinction; but Robcspierre had Il
impose ON the minds of the vulgar, and he
knew how to bcguile them, by accommodate
ing his flntterv to their passions and scale ot
understanding, by acts Of cunning and by
pocrisy, which weigh more with the multi
tnde than the words of eloqueuce, or the ar
guments Of wisdom. The people listened a!
&c their Cicero, when he twangcd out his a.
postrophies of Pouurc Peufir, PeHtte DER
tueur., and fastened 10 execute whatever
came recommended by such honied phrases
though devised by the worst of men for the
worst and most inhuman Of purposes.


Vanity was Robespierre's ruling passion
and though his countcnance was the image
OF his mind, he was vain even OF his personal
appearance, and never adopted the external
habits of q sans culotte, Amongst his fellow
iacobins. he was distinguished by the nicely
with which his hair was arranged and pow
dered: and the neatncss ef his dress was
carefully arranged and attended to, so as tC
cnunterbalancc If possible, the vulglarity
Of his person. His apartments though


small. were elegant. and vanity had filled
them with Representations of the occupant
bespierre's picture II length, hung in one
place, his miniature in another, aud his bust
occupied niche, and on III" table were
disposed few metallona exhibiting his
head in profile. The vani'% which all this
indicated was of the coltleat and most selfish
character, being snch as considers neglect
as insult, and receives homage merely as q
tribute so that, while praise is received
without gratitude, it rs withheld at the risk
of mortal hate. Self-love of this danger


ous character is closely allied with envy


and Robcspierre was one OF the most envi-
ous and vindictivc men that ever lived. He
never was known to pardon any opposition,
aifront, or even rivalry; aud to be marked
in his tablets on such an account. was sure
Though perhaps not al immediate sentence
of death. Danton was hero, compared
with this cold, calculating, creeping miscre-
ant; for his passions, thongh exaggerated


had at least some touch of humanity. and his
brutal ferocitv was supported by brutal cour-
; age. Rnbespicrre was coward. who sign
; ed death warrants with hand that shook,
though his heart was relentless. He pos
r sessed no passions on which to charge his
crimes; they were perpetrated in cold blood,
and upon mature deliberation.


Marat, the third of this Internal triumvi-
rate, had attracted the attention of the low
er orders. by the violence of his sentiments


in the journal which he conducted from the

BY the schooner Eliza Piggot, Davis, arrived
at this port, Mr.. Sanderson, ofthe Coffee House.
has received letter dated Laguayra, March.
18th, Of which the following is an extract.


81 enclose you the first copy Of the "I.ira.na
new paper, which it is intended to publish at
Caracas You will therein find that the Grand
American Federation is spoken Of Bolivar,
resi- ignation is also therein. His resignation ;s
however, only to pave the way to place hi,nselfa
step higher, as there is little doubt that four
months viii not clapse, before there will be n
union OF Peru, Colombia and Bolivia, and Boil
iyar appointed President for life:"


The project OF union of Bolivia Peru, and
Colombia, is highly applaudcd in thc 'Lra
The cause of liberty in general is not likely to
be advanced by the confederation of military re.
publlcs; but it is generally supposed that anv
kind Of government is preferable to anarchy"
ABDICATION OF THE LIBERATOR.


HEAD QUARTERS, Caracas, Fc6. 6, 1927.
To his excellency the President Of the Hon


orable body of the Senate.


Nos, L.rceArnt Sir:--In 10 former cir.
cumstances has the august autority of Con-
gres, been of snch necessity TO the republic
as. at this present period, in which every
mind has been disturbed. and the whole ma.
ton agltated, by internal connections.


Called by your eXcellcncy to take the
oath of office as President of the republic,
arrived at the capital, whence was spcedi-
ly summoned to the departments of the an.
clent Venezuela. From Bogota to this CITY
| have issued DEGREES so important that.
make bold to declare it of the greatest mo-
mcnt, that your exccllency should call the
attention OF Congress to them, and request
that body from me, to take them into their
wise consideration. If have overstepped
the boundaries of my authority, the fault
lies solely with me; but ! willingly conse-
crate even my innocence to the safety OF the
republic. This sacrifice wa, required Of me,
and glory in not having delayed it.


When in Peru. an official notice brought
me intelligence of my elevation, by the peo-
Pile, to the Presidency of the republic, de-
clined to the executive power the accept
ance OF the chief magistracy Of the nation.-
For fourteen years have I filled the Office of
supreme head and President Of the republic;
dangers forced this duty upon me, which no
longer existing. leave me at liberty to retire
to the cnjoyments of private life.


beg of Congress to cast a regard upon
the situation Of Colombia, of America, and
OF the entire world. Every thing seems to
tiatter us. There is not Spaniard upon
the American continent. Domestic peace
has rcigned III Colombia since the COM
menccment of the present year. MANY
powerful nations recognize our political cx-
istencc and some are Joined to us in the
bonds OF amity and friendship. A large por-
tion OF the American states arc in alliance
with Colombia. and Spain is at present me.
naced by Great Britain. What more can
we hope forl The womb of time can alone
contain the ilnmcnsty of happiness which
has been prepared for us by bountiful
Providence, in whom is our only reliance.


As for me. suspicious of tyrancal usur-
patton rest upen my name, and disturb the
hearts of the Colombians. Republicans jeal-
Gus OF their liberties cannot consider me
without secret dread, because the pages OF
history tell them that all those placed in
similar situations have been ambitious. In
vain DO wish to propose the example of
Washington as my defence; and in fact, one
or many exceptions can effect nothing "a
ganst the experience of the world, which
mas always been oppressed by the powerful
l sigh between the distresses of my fellow
citl2cns, and the sentence which awaits
me in the judgment of postcrity. | myself
am aware that am not free from ambition;
and therefore, desire to extricate myself
from the grasp H that fury, to free my fe-
low citizens from all inquictude, and to Sc
cure after my death that reputation which
may be entitled to for my zeal in the cause
of liberty. With such sentiments renounce,
again and again, the presidency of the re-
public. Congress and the nation must re-
ccive this abdcation AS irrevocable.


Nothing will be able to obllge me to con-
tlnue in the service, to which have already
dedicated my entire life. And now that the
triumph of liberty has placed this sublime
right within the enjoyment OF every one,
shall alone be deprived of it? Mo- The
Congress and the Colombian people are just;
they will not compel me to an ignominious
descrtion. Few are the days which remain
to me; more than two-thirds Of my exis-
tencc has already passed; let me. therefore,
be permitted to wait peaceful death in
the obscure and silent retreat of my pater-
nal residence. My sword and my heart will,
nevertheless. be always with Colombia.
and my last sigh will assend to Heaven in
prayers for her continual prosperity.


pray, therefore. Congress aud my fellow
citizens, to confer on me the title of hrivate
citizen.


God guard yonr cxcellency.

From the Philadelphia Gazette.

barrels oflime for the arrest Of barber who
had run away with his wife

tie several sums hereby appropriated shall be

erwise appropriated.

OH why say that woman is faithless and light,
And that wisdom alone to thy sex is confined,
That her heart is As false as her beauty is bright
And her loyeEness is in her face, not her Inindf
Remember 'twas woman first ul'd thee to rest,
Remember twas she that first over thee hung :
That thou slept thy first sleep on "omans

And thy first infant accents were caught from
her tongue!
She guided thy steps in thy infantne years.
She anxiously watched when thy careless feet
strayed;
She hushed all thy wailing, she dried all thy

And delighted she saw thy young genius dis
played.


And is not fair woman the swect'ner Of life
With man she divides her enjoyments and
- cares;
& The friend or the sister, the daughter or Wife

She is like the fair woodbine that wreath.
round the oak,
hat oSitVCS AVS support AoH siiN HS~ 'oDte
stem


And tho it be scathed by the lightning's dread

Still weaycs of its fow'rets rich dia,lern.

cline,


She drops DER his woes the pure plying tear

will twine-

Ills she that will watch the last litt-lrop de
part


From the cheek where SO ostcn her smile la:
removed


The dark cloud-then vii! feel the last throt
of the heart,
And weep DER the corpse of the being she

She will freely confess she is weaker than thee,

OH thou shoulds't remember the momen


when she


Has cheer'd thee and seemed Ike q form fror
above


70 thee foi instruction and strength SIZE mus

Tor sh;: does not pretend to be wise ast'on art

Her feelings are not from the head, Dat tn


heart


Then why say she only by malice is stirred

oh revoke the rude sentence, recall the harsl


word


And woman henceforth shall be ever thy friend

Rohesplerre, to ayenge his injured vanity, OF
to remove rival whom he envled; Marat,
from the same instructive love Oh oiooo,
which induces a wolf to continue his ravaBc
of the focks long after his hunger is appeas-
ed.''


"Danton despised Robespierre for his
cowardice, Robespierre feared the ferocious
audacity of Danton, and with him, to tear
was to hate--and to hate was-when the
hour arrived--to destroy They differed IN
their ideas also of the mode OF exercising
their terrible system Of government. Danton
had often in his mouth the sentence OF Ma
chiaval, that when it becomes necessary to
shed blood, a single great massacre has


more dreadfnl effect than series OF success
i've exer.ions. Robespierre. on the contra.
ry, preferred the latter, rs the best way OF
sustaining the reign Of terror The appe-
tite of Marat could not be satiated but by
combining both modes Of murder both
Danton and Robespierre kept aloof from the
sanguinary Marat.


Among the three monsters mentioned,
Danton had that energy which the Giron-
dists wanted and was we'll acquainted with
the secret movrnents OF those insurrections
TO which they possessed no key. His vices
of wrath, luxury, love Cf spoil, dreadful as
they were, arc attributes OF mortal men;-
the envy OF Rohespierre, and the instructive
blood-thirstiness Of Marat were the proper
ties of hends. Danton, like the huge SER
pent called the Boa, might be approached
with degree Of safety when gorged with
prey; but the appetite of Marat tor blood
was like the horse lccch, which says, Not
cnough--an,: the slaughterous envy of Rob-
espierre was like the knawing worm that
dieth not, and yields no Interval OF repose.-
In glutting Danton with spoil, and furnish
ing the means of indulgins his luxury, the
Girondists might have purchased his sup
port; but nothing under the supreme rule of
France would have gratiicd Eobcspierre,-
and AN unlimited torrent of the blood of that
unhappy country, could alone have satiated
I Marat. II 4 colleague was to be chosen cut
OF that dctrstab,c triumvirate, uuquestiona-
bly, Dantpn was 10 be considered the most
eligible

night, instead Of yesterday moruing, yben
Mr.. Baxter was to have exhibited 4 ~
rather run off with his money. leaving il to to
stockholders he gave nothing but evasiors sHe
and they deterH;ned to open the door Of the

name ot Greensbung Baxter has been for

naily self moving water wheel. A number
were found sufficiently credulous to be gull
ed into the belief that perpetual motion was
discovered. and company was forthwith
formed and all the shares taken up at once
At Is stated that so great was the infatuation
that the shares actually rose from trife to
one thousand dollars. Suspicion was excit-
ed at meeting Of the directors on Thurs day
evening" and they determined upon inspect
,nE TIE mysteries ut the marhine tha, very

full articles.headline: PORTER AND LABORDE.
full articles.article:
The ship Lafayette, which arrived at N.
York on Saturday last. was boarded on the
10th inst. off Key West. by boat from
brig of war, one of the Spanish squadron,
The boarding officer was an acquaintance OF
a Spanish gentleman, passenger in the La
fayette. and informed him that Commodore
l.aborde had sent formal challenge "
Com. Porter. to meet him in fair engage.

full articles.headline: lllE ntlNs Of BABYLON
full articles.article:
The local circumference has been found
TO he .lSS feet, which gives to the ruins 4
much greater extrnt uf base than the origi-
nal building Thc surplus is very great,
"nen one considers the qaantity that must
have been removed by the Macedonian SOL
diers, aud hos much, in the course OF ages,
must have been taken by the workmcn en-
ployed in digging for bricks. lhc elevation
ut the mound is irregular 10 tile west it is
,9S feet high Ga the top is that which
looked like castle in the distance; it is a
solid mass ci kiln blrnt bricks, thirty seven
feet high, and twenty-eight broad. The
bricks, which are ct ali excellent desciip-
ton, are laid in with fine and scarce.
y perceptiblc cement. At regular inter-
yals, some bricks are omitted so as to leave
square apertures through the mass these
may possibly have been intended to procure
free current Of air, that should prevent the
admission OF damp into the brick work. The
summit Of the mass is much broken, and the
fractures are 80 made as to carry conviction
that violence has been used to reduce it to
this state.


Distant from the pile oi bricks Just describ
ed, and lower down on the north face of the
large mound, IS another mass exactly SINH
lar. Pieces Of marble, stones, and broken
bricks. iie scattered over the ruin. The
most curious Of the fragments are several
mis-shapen masses OF brick work quite
black, except in few places where regular
layers Of kiln-burnt bricks are disccrnabe:
these have certainly been subjected to some
fierce heat, as they are completely molten
ia strong presumption that fire was used
in the destruction OF the tower; which, in
parts, resembles that what the scriptures
prophcsicd il should become, IA burnt munh
tain"


Travellers who have visited this spot have
been struck with the curious appearance Of
these fragments, and having only seen the
black fee, have altogether rejected
the idea of their being bricks. In the de-
nnncations respecting Babylon. fire is par
tcnlarly mentioned as an agent against it,
10 this Jeremiah evidently alludes, when
he says that it should be as "whrn God o.
yerthrew Sodom and Comorrah," on which
cities, it is said ''the Lord rained fire and
birthstone" Again. 81 will kindle fire in
his cities, and it shall devour all round about
him" and in another place, cher high gates
shall be burned with fire, and the people
shall labonr in vain, and the folk in the fire,
and they shall be weary"


Taking into calculation the brick mass On
the top of the large mound, tne runs are
two hundred and thirty five fett.hgh, which
gives nearly half the height of the tower in
its perfect state. Rich thought he could
trace four stages or stories of this building;
and the united observations of our party in
duce the same conviction.


Wild beasts appeared to be as numerous
here as at Mujillele. Mr.. Lamb gave up
his examination, from seeing an animal
crouched in one of the square aperturcs.
saw another in n similar situation, and the
large Footprint of lion was so fresh, that
the beast must have stolen away on our ap-
preach. From the summit we had view
of the vast heaps which constitute all that
now remains of ancient Babylon; more
complete picture of desolation could not be


imagined. The eye wandered over bar
rem desert, in which ruins were the only in
dication that it had ever been ,nhabited.-
It was impossible TO behold this scene, and
not to be reminded how exactly the predic-
tion of Isaiah ard Jeremiah have been full
filled, even in the appearance Babylon was
doomed to present: that "she should never
be nhabited;" that "the Arabian should not
pitch his tent there" that she would ',be-
become heaps" that her cities should be
"a desolation, dry land, and Wilderness"


Cant KrhhePs hersonai Narrative.

PUBLIC-No. 20.


AN ACT to extend the time Of issuing and locat-
ing Military Land Warrants to Officers and Sol
diers of the Revolutionary Army.


Be il enacted by the Senate and House of
Representatives Of the United States Of II
merica in Congress Assembicd, That the
time limited by the second section of the Act
approved, the twenty fourth day of February,
one thousand eight hundred and nineteen, for is
suing military Land Warrants to the Officers and
Soldiers Of the Revolutionary Army, shall be ex-
tended till the fourth day Of March, one thous.
and eight hundred and thirty; and the time fo,
locating the indicated warrants shall be extend
ed till the first day ofOctober thereafter.
APPROVED: March 2, 1897.

full articles.headline:
From the .imer,cd,, Quarterly Reuiela.
DANTON. ROBESpIERRE, AND MARAT
full articles.article:
DANTON, ROBESPlEKRE, AND Mhhhi'


We come, next, to the Legislative As
sembiy, Gin which there was no party, that
could be termed strictly or properly royal
ists." It's three divisions, the Constitution
alists, the Girondists, or Brissotins and the
Jacobins, are exhibited in their diversity OF
traits and objects; their relentless mutual
strife, and their common warfare against
the wretched king. The Girondists and the
Jacebins stood ready "to storm together tne
last bulwarks of the monarchy"-but the
latter were resolved and destined to monop-
olize the spoil, and establish the incttable'
incompatible Reign Of Terror. Robes
pierre, SAYS Scott. might be CONSIDERED as
the head of the Jacobins, if they had, IN
deed leader. more than two wolves nave
which tune their united voices to cry OF MN
that bays .hc loudest" Mdrdt loved TO
talk of murder as soldiers do OF battles, and
made, con dm0re, an exact calcuia'loh 10
shaw in what manner tzoo hundred ana S'1-
, ty thousand aristocrats might be Dutchered
in a day. The two peerless rufflans, ana
their condign associate, Ddnton, are thus
portrayed in the second volume -


"Ihree men of terror, whose names VIII
long remain, we trust, unmatched III histo-
~ BY those Of any similar mlscreants, had
1
and were called the triumviratc.


I Danton deserves to, be named first, as un-
rivaled by his colleagues in talent and au-
dacity. He was man of gigantic size, and
possessed voice Of thunder, His counte-
nance WAS that of an Orge on the shoulders
OF a Hercules. He was as fond of the pleas
urcs of vice as Of the practice of cruclty'
and it was id THAT there were times when he
became humani2ed amidst his dcbauchery,
| laughed at the terror which his furious dec
/ lamations excited, and might be approached
with safety. ike the Maelstrom at the turn
of tide. II p,ofision was inlulgcd to an
extent hazardous to his potMlaritv, for the
populace are jcalous ola lavish expenditure,
AS raising their favoritcs too much above
their owu d gree: and the charge OF spccu
lltiun finds always ready credit with them,
when brought agains. public men.


Rohcspcrre possessed this advantage over
Danton, that he did not seem to seek fG'
wealth. either for hording or expenains, bG'
lived in strict and economical retirement, tc
Justify the name of thr Incorrtptiblc, wi;h
which he was honored BY his partizaps. He
appears to have possessed little talents, saw
ing q dcep fund Vt hypncrisv, considerable
powers Of sophistry, and Il cold exaggerated
strain Of oratorv, as foreign 70 good taste, a'
the measures he recommended were 70 or
binary humanity. II Itseemed wonderful that
even the serthiue and boiling Of the revoil'
tionarv cauldron. should have sent up trou
the bottom, and long supported OH the sur
! face, a thing so miserabv void Of claims Il
public distinction; but Robcspierre had Il
impose ON the minds of the vulgar, and he
knew how to bcguile them, by accommodate
ing his flntterv to their passions and scale ot
understanding, by acts Of cunning and by
pocrisy, which weigh more with the multi
tnde than the words of eloqueuce, or the ar
guments Of wisdom. The people listened a!
&c their Cicero, when he twangcd out his a.
postrophies of Pouurc Peufir, PeHtte DER
tueur., and fastened 10 execute whatever
came recommended by such honied phrases
though devised by the worst of men for the
worst and most inhuman Of purposes.


Vanity was Robespierre's ruling passion
and though his countcnance was the image
OF his mind, he was vain even OF his personal
appearance, and never adopted the external
habits of q sans culotte, Amongst his fellow
iacobins. he was distinguished by the nicely
with which his hair was arranged and pow
dered: and the neatncss ef his dress was
carefully arranged and attended to, so as tC
cnunterbalancc If possible, the vulglarity
Of his person. His apartments though


small. were elegant. and vanity had filled
them with Representations of the occupant
bespierre's picture II length, hung in one
place, his miniature in another, aud his bust
occupied niche, and on III" table were
disposed few metallona exhibiting his

character, being snch as considers neglect
as insult, and receives homage merely as q
tribute so that, while praise is received
without gratitude, it rs withheld at the risk
of mortal hate. Self-love of this danger


ous character is closely allied with envy


and Robcspierre was one OF the most envi-
ous and vindictivc men that ever lived. He
never was known to pardon any opposition,
aifront, or even rivalry; aud to be marked
in his tablets on such an account. was sure
Though perhaps not al immediate sentence
of death. Danton was hero, compared
with this cold, calculating, creeping miscre-
ant; for his passions, thongh exaggerated


had at least some touch of humanity. and his
brutal ferocitv was supported by brutal cour-
; age. Rnbespicrre was coward. who sign
; ed death warrants with hand that shook,
though his heart was relentless. He pos
r sessed no passions on which to charge his

BY the schooner Eliza Piggot, Davis, arrived
at this port, Mr.. Sanderson, ofthe Coffee House.
has received letter dated Laguayra, March.

81 enclose you the first copy Of the "I.ira.na
new paper, which it is intended to publish at
Caracas You will therein find that the Grand
American Federation is spoken Of Bolivar,
resi- ignation is also therein. His resignation ;s

The project OF union of Bolivia Peru, and

The cause of liberty in general is not likely to

ABDICATION OF THE LIBERATOR.


HEAD QUARTERS, Caracas, Fc6. 6, 1927.
To his excellency the President Of the Hon


orable body of the Senate.


Nos, L.rceArnt Sir:--In 10 former cir.
cumstances has the august autority of Con-
gres, been of snch necessity TO the republic
as. at this present period, in which every
mind has been disturbed. and the whole ma.
ton agltated, by internal connections.


Called by your eXcellcncy to take the
oath of office as President of the republic,
arrived at the capital, whence was spcedi-
ly summoned to the departments of the an.
clent Venezuela. From Bogota to this CITY
| have issued DEGREES so important that.
make bold to declare it of the greatest mo-
mcnt, that your exccllency should call the
attention OF Congress to them, and request
that body from me, to take them into their
wise consideration. If have overstepped
the boundaries of my authority, the fault
lies solely with me; but ! willingly conse-
crate even my innocence to the safety OF the
republic. This sacrifice wa, required Of me,
and glory in not having delayed it.


When in Peru. an official notice brought
me intelligence of my elevation, by the peo-
Pile, to the Presidency of the republic, de-
clined to the executive power the accept
ance OF the chief magistracy Of the nation.-
For fourteen years have I filled the Office of
supreme head and President Of the republic;
dangers forced this duty upon me, which no
longer existing. leave me at liberty to retire
to the cnjoyments of private life.


beg of Congress to cast a regard upon
the situation Of Colombia, of America, and
OF the entire world. Every thing seems to
tiatter us. There is not Spaniard upon
the American continent. Domestic peace
has rcigned III Colombia since the COM
menccment of the present year. MANY
powerful nations recognize our political cx-
istencc and some are Joined to us in the
bonds OF amity and friendship. A large por-
tion OF the American states arc in alliance
with Colombia. and Spain is at present me.
naced by Great Britain. What more can
we hope forl The womb of time can alone
contain the ilnmcnsty of happiness which
has been prepared for us by bountiful
Providence, in whom is our only reliance.


As for me. suspicious of tyrancal usur-
patton rest upen my name, and disturb the
hearts of the Colombians. Republicans jeal-
Gus OF their liberties cannot consider me
without secret dread, because the pages OF
history tell them that all those placed in
similar situations have been ambitious. In
vain DO wish to propose the example of
Washington as my defence; and in fact, one
or many exceptions can effect nothing "a
ganst the experience of the world, which
mas always been oppressed by the powerful
l sigh between the distresses of my fellow
citl2cns, and the sentence which awaits
me in the judgment of postcrity. | myself
am aware that am not free from ambition;
and therefore, desire to extricate myself
from the grasp H that fury, to free my fe-
low citizens from all inquictude, and to Sc
cure after my death that reputation which
may be entitled to for my zeal in the cause
of liberty. With such sentiments renounce,
again and again, the presidency of the re-
public. Congress and the nation must re-
ccive this abdcation AS irrevocable.


Nothing will be able to obllge me to con-
tlnue in the service, to which have already
dedicated my entire life. And now that the
triumph of liberty has placed this sublime
right within the enjoyment OF every one,
shall alone be deprived of it? Mo- The
Congress and the Colombian people are just;
they will not compel me to an ignominious
descrtion. Few are the days which remain
to me; more than two-thirds Of my exis-
tencc has already passed; let me. therefore,
be permitted to wait peaceful death in
the obscure and silent retreat of my pater-
nal residence. My sword and my heart will,
nevertheless. be always with Colombia.
and my last sigh will assend to Heaven in
prayers for her continual prosperity.


pray, therefore. Congress aud my fellow
citizens, to confer on me the title of hrivate
citizen.


God guard yonr cxcellency.
